docs.snippet: Because of an editing error, a front-page article yesterday about the addition of Google's chief executive, Eric E. Schmidt, to the Apple Computer board referred imprecisely to the origins of Pixar, the digital film studio led by Apple's co-founde...
docs.lead_paragraph: Because of an editing error, a front-page article yesterday about the addition of Google's chief executive, Eric E. Schmidt, to the Apple Computer board referred imprecisely to the origins of Pixar, the digital film studio led by Apple's co-founder, Steven P. Jobs. It grew out of Lucasfilm's computer graphics division, which Mr. Jobs purchased in 1986; he did not found it outright. The article also misstated the middle initial of a former colleague of Mr. Schmidt's at Sun Microsystems. He is William N. Joy, not William V.

docs.snippet: INTERIOR AGENCY CRITICIZED -- The inspector general of the Interior Department accused top agency officials of tolerating widespread ethical failures, from cronyism to cover-ups of incompetence, and then dismissing criticisms with ''a promise not ...
docs.lead_paragraph: INTERIOR AGENCY CRITICIZED -- The inspector general of the Interior Department accused top agency officials of tolerating widespread ethical failures, from cronyism to cover-ups of incompetence, and then dismissing criticisms with ''a promise not to do it again.'' [Page A1.] GOOGLE'S APPROACH TO CHARITY -- Larry Page, left, and Sergey Brin, founders of Google, have set up a philanthropy, giving it seed money of about $1 billion and a mandate to tackle poverty, disease and global warming. But unlike most charities, this one will be for-profit, allowing it to fund start-up companies, form partnerships with venture capitalists, and even lobby Congress. It will also pay taxes. [A1.] WOLFOWITZ'S CORRUPTION FIGHT -- As president of the World Bank, Paul D. Wolfowitz has made the fight against corruption in poor countries a hallmark issue, and he has drawn criticism for an aggressive campaign that has led to the suspension of hundreds of millions of dollars in loans and contracts to countries including India, Chad and Bangladesh. [C1.] U.S. WARNS CHINA -- In the administration's toughest warning yet to China on economic issues, Treasury Secretary Henry M. Paulson Jr. said that Chinese leaders were imperiling their nation's future by engaging in policies that Americans and others see as unfair. [C3.] NINTENDO TO RELEASE CONSOLE -- Nintendo of Japan plans to announce that it will release its new Wii video game console in North America and South America on Nov. 19, just as the holiday shopping season begins, and that the machine will cost $250 in the United States. The move may allow Nintendo to take advantage of stumbles by its main rival, Sony. [C1.] MICROSOFT VS. HACKER -- A solitary computer hacker has entangled Microsoft in a battle of wits by repeatedly releasing a free program to strip away the software lock that the company created to protect digital movies and songs from being freely copied by Internet users. [C5.] HIGH HOPES FOR ONLINE GAME -- AOL and Mark Burnett, producer for reality television, kicked off an ambitious online game called ''Gold Rush,'' which they hope will become a national sensation somewhat on par with the one Mr. Burnett created six years ago with the ''Survivor'' series. [C3.] STRONG EARNINGS AT LEHMAN -- Lehman posted strong third-quarter results amid weak markets, lackluster deal flow and higher global interest rates, and its shares surged. [C13.] MARKETS RISE -- Stocks rose, sending major indexes to their highest levels since May, as battered energy shares like Exxon Mobil rebounded and investors bet that interest rates would not rise any time soon. [C13.] ROUGH TIME FOR NISSAN CHIEF -- Despite Carlos Ghosn's gilded reputation, his companies, Renault and its partner, Nissan Motor Corporation, are not performing well right now -- a fact their boss readily acknowledges. [C1.] CHICAGO WAGE EFFORT FAILS -- The first attempt in the nation to impose minimum wage regulations on big-box stores like Wal-Mart unraveled as Chicago's City Council fell three votes short of overriding Mayor Richard M. Daley's veto. [A18.] PLAN FOR JOBLESS INSURANCE -- The unemployment insurance system, which has hardly changed since its inception in 1935, should be revamped to aid more workers displaced by a transforming economy, economists said as they released overhaul plans. [A21.] HELP FOR WHITE-COLLAR WORKERS -- Barbara Ehrenreich, author of ''Nickel and Dimed,'' has started an organization called United Professionals to help white-collar workers, be they unemployed, uninsured, downsized, stressed out or merely anxious. [A21.] H.P. AND SPYING CASE -- California prosecutors looking into the Hewlett-Packard spying case are focusing on a small private investigation firm operating out of a house in suburban Boston. It is not clear how such a tiny firm ended up handling work for H.P., one of the largest technology companies. But other private investigators said it was not surprising, because corporations who are in need of such services often end rely on subcontractors. [C1.] TRIAL SET FOR DIRECT MARKETER -- The lawsuit in which the coupon company Valassis Communications seeks to cancel its $1.3 billion merger agreement with the direct-mail marketer Advo will go to trial in December, a judge ruled. [C5.] ONLINE A BANK REBUILDS -- Gary Rivlin of The Times spoke with chief executive of Liberty Bank, Alden J. McDonald Jr., about struggling to rebuild after Hurricane Katrina. An audio report is at nytimes.com/business. ETHANOL USE -- As proponents of ethanol push for its use, Alexei Barrionuevo of The Times went on a road trip through the Midwest to find out how available the fuel is to the American driver. His report is at nytimes.com/business. ONLINE: DEALBOOK -- A report on mergers and acquisitions, up-to-the-minute news on Wall Street and a look at the behind-the-scenes maneuvering is at nytimes.com/dealbook. Business Briefing Articles on these developments are at nytimes.com/business. AIRBUS MAY DELAY DELIVERY of its A380 airliner by more than a year amid rising production costs, said Mike Turner, chief executive of BAE Systems, which owns 20 percent of Airbus. (BLOOMBERG NEWS) THE SUN-TIMES MEDIA GROUP, formerly Hollinger International Inc., said its chief executive, Gordon Paris, would step down at the end of the year as the newspaper publishing company shifts all of its New York-based corporate functions to Chicago. (AP)

headline.main: TODAY IN BUSINESS

docs.snippet: INTERNATIONAL A3-17    90 Killed or Found Dead On a Grim Day in Baghdad  Nearly 90 Iraqis were killed or found dead in Baghdad, an Iraqi Interior Ministry official said, making for a particularly grim day even amid the intense sectarian violence t...
docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-17 90 Killed or Found Dead On a Grim Day in Baghdad Nearly 90 Iraqis were killed or found dead in Baghdad, an Iraqi Interior Ministry official said, making for a particularly grim day even amid the intense sectarian violence that has gripped the capital. A10 Shooting at Montreal College A man carrying an automatic rifle shot and killed a woman and wounded 19 other people, several critically, at the campus of a junior college in Montreal. The gunman died after exchanging shots with police. A17 Resistance to Rape Law The Pakistani government has run into difficulties, including a postponed vote, in its efforts to pass a law to end the worst abuses suffered by women who report rape or are accused of adultery under an Islamic ordinance. A8 Report Criticizes Hezbollah Amnesty International accused Hezbollah of war crimes and ''serious violations of international humanitarian law'' during the Lebanon war. In August the group criticized Israel's behavior during the war. A17 Chinese Storm Claims Disputed China's emergency response to Typhoon Saomai in August was trumpeted as a triumph. But an internal report by the official New China News Agency, compiled in the days after the storm and intended just for the authorities, bluntly contradicted the official picture. A3 NATIONAL A18-25 Some Movement Is Seen On National Security Plans The White House took a critical step in its effort to get Congressional blessing for President Bush's domestic eavesdropping program, but it ran into increasingly fierce resistance from leading Republicans over its plan to try terror suspects being held at Guantánamo Bay. A1 Pet Projects Rule Is Delayed Leaders of the House of Representatives postponed consideration of a rule requiring individual lawmakers to sign their names to some of the pet projects they tuck into major tax and spending bills. A22 Big-Box Wage Rule Fails The first efforts to impose minimum-wage regulations on big-box stores like Wal-Mart unraveled in Chicago, as its City Council fell three votes short of overriding Mayor Richard M. Daley's veto of the measure. A18 Push to Repeal Military Law Gay rights groups are making the biggest push in nearly a decade to repeal a 1993 law, known as ''Don't Ask, Don't Tell,'' that bars openly gay people from serving in the military. A18 Border Fence Plan in House House Republicans announced that they would move swiftly to pass legislation requiring the Bush administration to build 700 miles of fencing along the Mexican border to help stem the flow of illegal immigrants and drugs. A24 NEW YORK/REGION B1-6 An Immigrant's Tale Turns Out to Be Just That Genealogical researchers have uncovered the truth about Annie Moore, the immigrant memorialized by bronze statues in New York Harbor and in Ireland. She was indeed the first immigrant to set foot on Ellis Island -- but she did not, as legend has it, go to Texas, marry a descendant of the Irish liberator Daniel O'Connell and die under the wheels of a streetcar. A1 A Letter From a Priest A letter written in 1984 by Msgr. Charles M. Kavanagh, the former chief fund-raiser for the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York, to the parents of a man who accuses the priest of abusing him as a teenager has resurfaced. The man says the letter shows that Monsignor Kavanagh touched him in a sexual manner. B1 Thoughts on Longevity Asian women in Bergen County, N.J., -- who live longer than any other ethnic subgroup of people anywhere in the nation, according to federal statistics -- attribute their longevity to a healthy diet, belief in God and their close-knit communities. B1 OBITUARIES D8 Governor Ann Richards The former governor of Texas, a witty and flamboyant Democrat who went from homemaker to national political celebrity, she was 73. D8 BUSINESS DAY C1-14 Interior Department Ethics The Interior Department's inspector general, Earl E. Devaney, responsible for investigating abuses and overseeing operations, accused the top officials at the agency of tolerating widespread ethical failures. A1 Google Founders' Charity The founders of Google, the popular search engine company, have set up a philanthropy, giving it seed money of about $1 billion. But unlike most charities, this one will be for-profit. A1 Business Digest C2 EDITORIAL A26-27 Editorials: Port security won't bankrupt us; extreme tuberculosis; Verlyn Klinkenborg on the death of a farmer. Columns: David Brooks, Bob Herbert. Bridge: E9 TV Listings: E11 Crossword: E8 Weather: D7

headline.main: News Summary

docs.snippet: The Times told readers last spring that Google had decided to stop being the outsider, and go full force into the ultimate insider's game of lobbying. In that article, we mentioned the Republican heavy-hitters, among them the DCI group well-connec...
docs.lead_paragraph: The Times told readers last spring that Google had decided to stop being the outsider, and go full force into the ultimate insider's game of lobbying. In that article, we mentioned the Republican heavy-hitters, among them the DCI group well-connected to Karl Rove and Ken Mehlman, as well as bipartisan firms they were hiring, PodestaMattoon among them. At that time, they were considering setting up a a political action committee, but were a bit hesitant. Most of their donations in the '04 cycle had been to Democrats, and they'd been counseled since to be more bipartisan.

docs.snippet: YAHOO BIDS FOR FACEBOOK -- To woo Mark Zuckerberg, the 22-year-old founder of the social networking Web site Facebook, Yahoo has offered about $900 million for the company and said it would keep Mr. Zuckerberg in charge. [Page C1.]    PRESSURE ON ...
docs.lead_paragraph: YAHOO BIDS FOR FACEBOOK -- To woo Mark Zuckerberg, the 22-year-old founder of the social networking Web site Facebook, Yahoo has offered about $900 million for the company and said it would keep Mr. Zuckerberg in charge. [Page C1.] PRESSURE ON CHIEF OF H.P. Pressure is mounting on Mark V. Hurd, Hewlett-Packard's chief executive, to explain what appears to have been his greater role in the company's spying operation than was initially indicated. Yesterday, after his name figured in documents newly surfacing in the investigation, Hewlett-Packard's stock fell significantly for the first time since the revelations began early this month, closing down 5.19 percent. [C1.] BILLIONS TO FIGHT GLOBAL WARMING -- Sir Richard Branson, the British magnate, said that his personal profits from airlines and a rail company that he controls -- a sum he estimated at $3 billion over the next 10 years -- would be invested in developing energy sources that do not contribute to global warming. [C1.] LIKE MEDICARE, BUT PRIVATE -- A type of private insurance plan is gaining ground that looks little different from the basic coverage long available to anyone with a federally issued Medicare card. [C1.] MIGRANTS MISSING FROM FARMS -- Stepped-up border enforcement kept many illegal Mexican migrant workers out of California this year, farmers and labor contractors said, putting strains on the state's shrinking seasonal farm labor force. [A1.] SPINACH GROWERS SWITCH TACTICS -- Amid growing governmental pressure and public concern about an E. coli outbreak caused by contaminated spinach, California farmers promised new procedures for growing, handling and shipping their produce, in hopes of lifting a week-old government warning about the crop. [A15.] SHARES FALL ON FEAR OF SLOWDOWN -- Stocks fell after a report said factory activity shrank in the Mid-Atlantic region in September for the first time in over three years, prompting worries about a slowdown in the economy and corporate profits. [C8.] INQUIRY ON HEART IMPLANTS -- Ela Medical, a small producer of implantable heart devices, said it had received a subpoena from federal health care fraud officials seeking information about possible inducements paid by the company to doctors using its products. [C4.] RULES FOR MILITARY LIFE INSURANCE -- Congress has taken final action to approve a bill to tighten rules governing the marketing of life insurance and high-cost mutual funds to American military personnel. [C4.] DROPPING OIL ROYALTIES -- A top official at the Interior Department said that she would not try to recover $1.3 billion in royalties that the government has lost as a result of flawed oil and gas leases it signed in the late 1990's. [C2.] MORE DELAYS FOR A380 -- The European Aeronautic Defense and Space Company, the parent company of Airbus, confirmed that its troubled A380 would face still more delivery delay. [C7.] TRIBUNE MAY SELL SOME ASSETS -- The Tribune Company will consider selling some or all of its assets, which include 11 newspapers, 25 television stations and the Chicago Cubs, as a result of an agreement it worked out with its largest shareholder, the Chandler family. Dennis FitzSimons, above, the company's chief, said the agreement had ''eliminated impediments to any transactions we might want to do, and management will explore strategic alternatives.'' [C5.] MERCK OF GERMANY IN DEAL -- Merck of Germany said it would take control of Serono, a Swiss pharmaceutical maker, for $13.5 billion after failing to secure a merger with Schering, its German competitor. [C7.] NEXT STEP FOR GOOGLE ADS -- Google is turning to Madison Avenue to help persuade marketers that it can do more than display text. Advertising: Stuart Elliott. [C8.] ONLINE POGUE'S POSTS -- Nowadays, Apple is a media darling. But that hasn't always been the case, as David Pogue writes in his blog at pogue.blogs.nytimes.com. SCREENS -- The Times critic Virginia Heffernan takes a look at the explosion of Web video awards in her blog at screens.blogs.nytimes.com. Business Briefing Articles on these developments are at nytimes.com/business. FEDEX said that its quarterly profit rose 40 percent on strong growth in its international, ground and freight segments. (REUTERS) NIKE said net profit fell 13 percent as stock-based compensation hampered results. The quarter still exceeded estimates. (REUTERS) RITE AID, the drugstore chain, said that its quarterly loss narrowed as a result of an income tax benefit and increased sales of generic drugs. (BLOOMBERG NEWS) PALM said that profit for its fiscal first quarter slipped as it accounted for stock option expenses for the first time and grappled with slow sales growth amid tougher competition. (AP) CONAGRA FOODS said in a preliminary report that quarterly profit fell 66 percent from a year earlier, when results included a gain from the sale of stock in the Pilgrim's Pride Corporation. (BLOOMBERG NEWS) AN EXECUTIVE with the United States unit of Samsung Electronics of South Korea agreed to plead guilty and serve prison time for taking part in price fixing in the computer memory chip business, the Justice Department. (REUTERS)

docs.snippet: Kermit, Legos and questions about helping children appreciate green design....
docs.lead_paragraph: Do a Google search for "It's not easy being green," and you'll get more than 50 million hits. Humble Kermit had no idea what he was starting back in 1970 when he first lamented spending "each day the color of the leaves." Even though the contemplative Muppet sang of trees, mountains and oceans, it's kind of remarkable that his plaintive refrain (written by the lyricist Joe Raposo) has, in slightly amended form, become our most recognizable slogan for sustainable living: It's easy being green.

docs.snippet: LIGHT-CIGARETTE SMOKERS CAN SUE -- In a legal blow to the tobacco industry, a federal judge in Brooklyn ruled that people who smoked light cigarettes that were often promoted as a safer alternative to regular cigarettes can press their fraud claim...
docs.lead_paragraph: LIGHT-CIGARETTE SMOKERS CAN SUE -- In a legal blow to the tobacco industry, a federal judge in Brooklyn ruled that people who smoked light cigarettes that were often promoted as a safer alternative to regular cigarettes can press their fraud claim as a class-action suit. [Page A1.] VIACOM HEAD RESTRUCTURES PAY -- In another effort to restore investor confidence, Viacom said its chairman and controlling shareholder, Sumner M. Redstone, left, was restructuring his pay to more clearly align it with shareholder interest and to base it on the company's financial performance. [C1.] HOME MARKET COOLS -- After inching up slowly for most of the summer, the national median price of a previously owned home finally dipped into the red in August, to $225,000. It was the first time that prices of existing homes had fallen on a year-over-year basis in more than a decade. [C1.] INSURANCE COSTS SOAR -- Among the reasons that real estate is cooling in some of the hottest markets is the soaring cost of insurance. Along the coast from Texas to Maine, owners of apartments and houses are facing huge premium increases. [C1.] THE NEXT WAVE -- Companies like Samsung, Intel and NTT DoCoMo of Japan are spending heavily in a race to control crucial aspects of an evolving new technology known as fourth-generation wireless and to promote it as the next wave in Internet access. But its future is far from certain. [C1.] DOUBTS ABOUT AUTO ALLIANCE -- General Motors has raised doubts in talks with Renault of France and Nissan of Japan that a three-way alliance would yield the benefits that Renault and Nissan insist would result. The sides agreed to explore an alliance in discussions that began in July. Renault and Nissan say an alliance could cover operations as varied as purchasing, manufacturing and product development. [C1.] LIQUIDS BAN RELAXED -- Aviation officials eased the ban on carry-on liquids for airline passengers, after testing to determine how much liquid explosive would cause catastrophic damage to a plane. [A14.] OIL IN RETREAT -- Crude oil prices dropped below $60 a barrel for the first time in six months before rebounding a bit, as nervous speculators retreated from the commodity markets. [C3.] OIL AND RATES LIFT STOCKS -- Stocks surged, with the Nasdaq rising more than 1 percent, as oil prices and interest rates hit multimonth lows, improving the outlook for corporate profits. The Nasdaq composite index jumped 30.14 points to 2,249.07, while the Dow Jones industrial average rose 67.71 points to 11,575.81. [C11.] COMPUTER POWER -- Google engineers will present a plan calling on the computer industry to create a simpler and more efficient power supply standard that they say will save billions of kilowatt-hours a year. [C3.] PATENT POLICY -- I.B.M. plans to publish its patent filings on the Web for public review as part of a policy that, if widely adopted, could help curb patent disputes and litigation. [C5.] PROGRESS ON A TINY SCALE -- A lengthy assessment for Congress says the United States continues to lead the world in research into nanotechnology -- manipulation of atoms and small clusters of molecules -- but the impact of the government's investment in the field may take decades to become apparent. [C6.] PANEL ADVISES HEALTH CARE ACTION -- A federal advisory panel, the Citizens' Health Care Working Group, said that Congress should take immediate steps to guarantee that all Americans have access to affordable health care by 2012. [A17.] HOUSE CALLS H.P. FIGURES -- Two Hewlett-Packard employees who directed the company's spying operations have been subpoenaed to appear before the House Energy and Commerce Committee after refusing invitations to testify. [C2.] ENERGY LEASE SALE BLOCKED -- The Interior Department's plan to sell oil and natural gas leases in northern Alaska was blocked by a federal judge who ruled that the department had failed to do a sufficiently broad analysis of the plan's environmental impact. [A15.] EUROPEAN UNION EXPANSION -- Romania and Bulgaria will receive qualified endorsement to join the European Union on Jan. 1, but the bloc will warn that expansion must then halt until the organization makes needed changes, the European Commission president said. [A5.] WALGREEN PROFIT RISES -- The Walgreen Company, the drugstore chain, posted a 25 percent increase in quarterly profit, driven by strong sales of prescription medications. Walgreen shares declined, however, as earnings before unusual items fell short of expectations. [C2.] ACQUITTAL IN WIRETAPPING CASE -- A former telephone company worker accused of lying to a grand jury in Los Angeles that is investigating the Anthony Pellicano wiretapping scandal was acquitted of most of the charges against her, dealing a sharp setback to federal prosecutors. [C8.] WACHOVIA TO PAY EX-BROKER -- Wachovia was ordered by a NASD arbitration panel to pay $3.8 million to a broker it fired in 2003 in connection with an investigation of improper trades. [C9.] SENTENCE IN FRAUD CASE -- The former chief executive of a paper manufacturer, American Tissue, was sentenced to 15 years in prison for organizing a fraud that cost banks and investors almost $300 million when the company collapsed. [C8.] WAVING THE FLAG -- Chevrolet, the brand that likened itself to baseball, hot dogs and apple pie in commercials in the 1970's, now hopes to kindle the same feelings by positioning the Silverado as America's truck, in ads that will begin running this weekend. Advertising. [C3.]

headline.main: Could Microsoft Bid for eBay?

docs.abstract: Some people like to spend their time speculating about the courtship habits of Hollywood stars like Jennifer Aniston and Vince Vaughn. Others prefer chattering about potential pairings of technology giants such as Yahoo and Google. For the latter group, the latest rumor making the rounds is the notion that software behemoth Microsoft might decide to [...]
